verses.text: After this, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them, and he took Gath and its villages from the hand of the Philistines.
verses.comment: This verse recounts David's decisive victory over the Philistines. The mention of 'Gath and its villages' signals David's expanding territory, foreshadowing the fulfillment of God's promise to establish his kingdom. Theologically, David as a conquering king prefigures Christ as the ultimate conqueror of spiritual enemies (see Matt. 12:29).

verses.text: He defeated Moab, and the Moabites became subject to David and brought him tribute.
verses.comment: The Moabites now bring tribute to David, showing his growing authority over neighboring nations. This typifies the manner in which all will one day acknowledge the rule of the Messiah, and the concept of offering tribute can be understood spiritually as worship and submission to God (Rom. 14:11).

verses.text: David also defeated Hadadezer king of Zobah at Hamath, as he went to establish his rule at the river Euphrates.
verses.comment: Here David fulfills the promise in Genesis 15:18 as his kingdom approaches the boundary of the Euphrates. There is a spiritual meaning in the expansion of the kingdom, foreshadowing the universal scope of Christ’s kingdom.

verses.text: David captured from him a thousand chariots, seven thousand charioteers, and twenty thousand foot soldiers. David hamstrung all the chariot horses except enough for one hundred chariots.
verses.comment: Hamstringing the horses limits Israel’s military reliance, in line with Deuteronomy 17:16, stressing trust in God over military power. This action also highlights themes of obedience and humility, values later perfected through Christ.

verses.text: When the Arameans of Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, David struck down twenty-two thousand men of the Arameans.
verses.comment: God demonstrates His protection of David by granting victory even against allied enemies, underscoring the divine support given to the chosen leader, and foreshadowing the triumph of Christ over powers opposed to his kingdom.

verses.text: Then David set up garrisons in Aram of Damascus, and the Arameans became subject to David, bringing him tribute. And the LORD gave victory to David wherever he went.
verses.comment: This passage highlights that David’s successes are attributed to the LORD’s favor, not merely his military skill. The spiritual principle here is divine providence and selection, echoing the way Christ's victory is given by the Father (see John 17:2).

verses.text: David took the shields of gold that were carried by the servants of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: David bringing the golden shields to Jerusalem prepares for the future temple worship. The accumulation of these items emphasizes the importance of sacred space and will later support liturgical worship in Jerusalem.

verses.text: From Tibhath and Cun, cities of Hadadezer, David took very much bronze. With it Solomon later made the bronze Sea, the pillars, and the vessels for the temple.
verses.comment: The bronze obtained here is used for constructing sacred vessels in the temple, foreshadowing the importance of physical elements in worship. The reference to 'the bronze Sea' connects to baptism and ritual purification, themes fulfilled spiritually by Jesus’ work.

verses.text: When Tou king of Hamath heard that David had defeated the whole army of Hadadezer king of Zobah,
verses.comment: This verse introduces Tou, whose response to David’s victory demonstrates the recognition of David’s divine authority, foreshadowing the universal acknowledgment of the messianic king.

verses.text: he sent his son Hadoram to King David to greet him and to bless him, because he had fought against Hadadezer and defeated him, for Hadadezer had been at war with Tou. He sent all kinds of articles of gold, silver, and bronze.
verses.comment: The sending of precious gifts signifies tribute and alliance, with deeper spiritual implications for offering gifts in worship and recognizing God’s chosen ruler. The act foreshadows bringing offerings to the true King in worship.

verses.text: King David dedicated these also to the LORD, with the silver and gold he had carried away from all the nations: Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, and Amalek.
verses.comment: David’s dedication of spoils hints at consecrating worldly goods for divine use, prefiguring spiritual acts of offering and the principle of dedicating the fruits of victory to God. This echoes the calling to offer everything to the Lord in worship.

verses.text: Moreover Abishai the son of Zeruiah killed eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
verses.comment: Abishai’s victory adds further to Israel’s security and illustrates the power of delegated leadership. Spiritually, this echoes Christ’s followers participating in the triumph of the true King.

verses.text: He put garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became subject to David. And the LORD gave victory to David wherever he went.
verses.comment: David's repeated success points to God's role in establishing the kingdom. This theme is later fulfilled as Christ’s kingdom expands over the nations, spiritually and tangibly, establishing his rule through his chosen church.

verses.text: So David reigned over all Israel, and he administered justice and righteousness for all his people.
verses.comment: David’s reign of justice and righteousness is idealized here, foreshadowing Messianic prophecy in Isaiah 9:7, fulfilled in Jesus’s perfect reign, and mirrored by the continuation of the kingdom through his appointed leaders.

verses.text: Joab the son of Zeruiah was over the army; Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was recorder;
verses.comment: David’s organized administration points to the growing complexity and order of God's kingdom, prefiguring the importance of apostolic succession and the involvement of various offices within the church.

verses.text: Zadok the son of Ahitub and Abimelech the son of Abiathar were priests; and Shavsha was secretary;
verses.comment: The priests and secretary are named, underscoring the importance of the priesthood and sacred administration. The united function of king and priest here prefigures the integrated nature of spiritual and sacramental leadership instituted by Christ.

verses.text: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites; and David’s sons were chief officials in the service of the king.
verses.comment: Benaiah's authority and David’s sons’ high office demonstrate roles for both royal and priestly service. This points to the principle of established hierarchy in the administration of God's people, paralleled in later ecclesial life and order.
